description: From Latin missilis (“that may be thrown”), neuter missile (“a weapon to be thrown, a javelin”), in plural missilia (“presents thrown among the people by the emperors”), from mittere (“to send”).  From 1611.  Compare Middle French missile (“projectile”), from 1636.

entries.meaning: Any object used as a weapon by being thrown or fired through the air, such as stone, arrow or bullet. [from 17th c.]
examples: The Rhodians, who used leaden bullets, were able to project their missiles twice as far as the Persian slingers, who used large stones.

entries.meaning: (military) A self-propelled projectile whose trajectory can be adjusted after it is launched. [from 20th c.]
examples: That missile is explosive enough to kill hundreds.
